source: Curated from LeetCode Discuss, Blind, and TeamBlind threads (2023-2024)
module: Module 12: Final Industry Simulation + Feedback Report

level_1: Q: How accurate are mock interviews? A: Did 3 mocks on Pramp - actual Google interview was 20% harder on system design.
Comment: Failed 4 mocks before realizing I wasn't clarifying constraints upfront (e.g., 'Is this for mobile or web?')
level_2: Q: Do companies share feedback reports? A: Got mine from Amazon - scored 2.8/4 on 'Invent & Simplify' with note: 'Solution lacked creative alternatives'.
Tip: Record yourself! Caught myself saying 'like' 50 times in 30 mins.
level_3: Q: Staff eng simulations? A: At Meta, they make you 'lead' a mock team through ambiguous requirements - scored on how you delegate.
Comment: My Netflix loop had a 'production outage' simulation - they cared more about communication than the fix.
level_4: Q: Director-level case studies? A: Had to present a 5-year tech roadmap to fake 'board members' who interrupted every 2 mins.
Comment: At Stripe EGM interview, they graded how I handled 'engineering vs sales' conflicts - not the technical solution.

level_1: Q: Beginner mock example? A: 'Debug a slow API endpoint' - trick was the interviewer wanted me to ask about monitoring tools first.
level_2: Comment: Microsoft's 'as-loop' simulation gives you a buggy PR and watches how you review code (they track comment politeness).
level_3: Q: Real FAANG simulation? A: Google L5 had me optimize ad targeting while a 'PM' kept changing requirements - tested pushback.
level_4: Comment: Two Sigma's hardest part wasn't the math - it was explaining quant models to a 'risk officer' actor who played dumb.

level_1: Q: Startup simulations? A: YC-style - 'Pitch your solution to a tired founder who hates tech debt.'
level_2: Comment: At Coinbase, they simulate explaining blockchain to a 'grandma' - tests if you can avoid jargon.
level_3: Q: Healthtech specifics? A: Had to design HIPAA-compliant APIs while a 'doctor' actor complained about UI.
level_4: Comment: SpaceX simulation: Debug satellite telemetry code while 'NASA' reps demand hourly updates.

level_1: Tip: Always restate the problem - my mock feedback said 'assumed wrong constraints 3/5 times'.
level_2: Q: How to think aloud? A: Use 'I'm considering X because Y, but Z might be better' - scored well at LinkedIn.
level_3: Comment: Staff eng secret: They want to hear 'How would my team implement this?' not just your solution.
level_4: Tip: For exec roles, frame tech debt as 'If we don't fix X, we lose $Y revenue in 6 months'.

level_1: Q: Common L3 problems? A: 'Design a rate limiter' but they care more about test cases than the code.
level_2: Comment: Amazon's OOD simulation gives you legacy code and says 'Make it scalable' - tests refactoring choices.
level_3: Q: L6 system design? A: Got 'Design Google Drive' but with focus on cross-region sync conflicts.
level_4: Comment: Goldman Sachs MD interview: Simulated telling a 'trader' their favorite feature is getting deprecated.

level_1: Quiz: Your mock feedback says 'Lacked structure' - what to improve? A) Use STAR B) Practice with timer C) Both
level_2: Q: How to grade mocks? A: Rate this response: 'I'd use Redis for caching' â†’ 'I'd use Redis with LRU eviction because our read pattern shows...'
level_3: Comment: Got a 3.5/4 at Google with note: 'Great algorithm but didn't discuss monitoring for edge cases'.
level_4: Q: Director feedback example? A: 'Visionary on tech but underestimated change management (2/5)'.

level_1: Task: Do a mock where you're not allowed to say 'um' - pay $1 to charity each time.
level_2: Comment: Built a feedback parser that highlights weak phrases ('kind of', 'maybe') - improved my clarity 40%.
level_3: Q: Staff eng prep? A) Run a mock design meeting where you 'manage' stubborn engineers (friends can roleplay).
level_4: Comment: Created 'bias bingo' cards for interview panels - catches phrases like 'not cultural fit' without evidence.

level_1: Mistake: Didn't bring a notebook - forgot key constraints mid-interview.
level_2: Tip: For 'failure' questions, end with 'Now I always X' - shows growth.
level_3: Mistake: Over-engineered a solution they wanted brute-force for MVP.
level_4: Pro Tip: For board simulations, prepare 3 financial metrics for every tech decision.
